properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms this afternoon and evening. These thunderstorms may be capable of producing very strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2019-08-19T02:42:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-18T14:43:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0596396064.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:26 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a dangerous thunderstorm capable of producing damaging wind gusts, up to toonie size hail and heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Thunderstorms have formed on the leading edge of a band of rain. One or two of these storms may become severe with damaging winds and some marginally severe hail being the primary threats. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.

properties.Summary:

Thunderstorms over the Lake St. Clair area are expected to keep tracking east this afternoon and evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:30 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a dangerous thunderstorm capable of producing damaging wind gusts, up to toonie size hail and heavy rain. A strong thunderstorm is located north of Wallaceburg and south of Sarnia is moving east at 60 km/h. Wind gusts near 120 km/h are possible along with hail. Locations impacted include: Petrolia, Oil Springs, Walpole Island, Port Lambton, Sombra, Courtright, Corunna, Becher, Avonry, Brigden, Bentpath, Oil City, Wyoming and Inwood. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. A slow moving low pressure system is giving heavy rain to parts of northern Manitoba. At Churchill, 10 mm of rain have already fallen during the night, and a further 15 to 30 mm are expected throughout today and tonight. The rain will taper off overnight or early Monday morning. Even higher amounts are likely north of Churchill along the Nunavut border where totals up to 50 mm are possible. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-19T01:31:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-18T09:32:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1445233959.2019
Area: Churchill
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:40 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts and up to nickel size hail. A line of thunderstorms southwest of Windsor is moving east at 80 km/h. Wind gusts near 90 km/h have been reported in this line. Locations impacted include: Amherstburg, LaSalle, South Windsor, McGregor, Maidstone and Essex. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. Heavy rain and strong winds beginning tonight over Arviat and ending Tuesday. A slow-moving low pressure system over northern Manitoba will bring heavy rain and strong east winds to southern Kivalliq beginning Sunday night. Total rainfall amounts will range between 30-40 mm by Tuesday morning before the rainfall starts to taper off. Easterly winds will increase Sunday night to 60 gusting to 80 km/h by Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-19T11:19:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-18T19:20:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3368634466.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm continues. Early-season heavy snow for part of the Alaska Highway. The combination of an unseasonably cold arctic airmass and Pacific moisture associated with a low on the North Coast will result in continued heavy snow for higher elevations between Fort Nelson and Watson Lake. Further snowfall accumulations of 15 to 35 cm are expected through today and tonight. The town of Fort Nelson should receive rain while areas south of Fort Nelson may see up to 10 cm. The heavy snow is forecast to ease Monday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-19T09:38:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-18T17:39:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0641734961.2019
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada
